channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Macedonia to Hold Early Elections Amid Political Turmoil
item.description: The agreement to hold elections in April was announced after eight hours of negotiations. The government has been under fire for months over a wiretapping scandal.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: Paris Police Clear Out Migrant Camp and Destroy Tents
item.description: The camp in north central Paris held 380 people, mostly from East Africa, who were moved to housing for asylum seekers or shelters.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Police officers evicted African migrants living in a camp under a subway bridge in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: New Battles Rage Near Aleppo Between Syrian Insurgents and ISIS
item.description: Insurgents opposed to the Islamic State said the group was exploiting Syrian government airstrikes against them to seize areas near Aleppo.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: On China’s Yangtze River, a Race Against Time to Find Survivors
item.description: More than a day after the Oriental Star capsized, most of the 456 people on board were still missing on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A rescue team carried a victim from the Yangtze River in China after a cruise ship capsized in high winds on Monday with hundreds on board.

item.title: Boko Haram Steps Up Attacks in Northeast Nigeria, Killing Scores
item.description: The intensification of the attacks, including a suicide bombing on Tuesday, began less than a week after Nigeria’s new president vowed to crush the group.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Anti-ISIS Coalition Makes Little Progress at Paris Meeting
item.description: The coalition of countries arrayed against the Islamic State has been hobbled by a variety of weaknesses.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Greece Challenges Creditors With New Proposal to Break Debt Impasse
item.description: Athens unveiled a plan to unlock financial aid, as creditors like the European Commission and I.M.F. were working on their own proposal.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, third from left, and French President François Hollande, third from right, during talks at the German chancellery Monday night.

item.title: Sepp Blatter to Resign as FIFA President
item.description: Four days after he was re-elected, Mr. Blatter said on Tuesday that he would resign his presidency of world soccer’s governing body in the wake of a corruption inquiry
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter said FIFA was in need of "a structural change of profound nature."

item.title: Hamas Forces Kill Leader of Islamic Splinter Group in Gaza
item.description: The fatal shooting came amid a campaign by Hamas to crack down on groups that follow the more radical Salafist stream of Islam, some of whom now adhere to the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Gunmen in Northern Afghanistan Kill 9 Local Aid Workers
item.description: The victims were two drivers, two guards and five staff members of the Czech charity People in Need, the group’s country director said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFA’s President, Sepp Blatter
item.description: Law enforcement officials said that Jérôme Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, made a 2008 bank transfer to a soccer official accused of taking a bribe.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Jérôme Valcke, right, the FIFA secretary general, shook hands with Sepp Blatter at last week's FIFA Congress.

item.title: Oriental Star Accident Highlights Dangers of Yangtze Cruises
item.description: As tourism to the region drops, cruise lines are cutting prices, and safety standards are falling, experts say.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A Yangtze River cruise ship in 2012 near Badong, China, about 60 miles from the Three Gorges dam in Hubei Province.

item.title: Aid Helicopter Crashes in Nepal, Killing 4
item.description: The helicopter, which was chartered by Doctors Without Borders, crashed northeast of Kathmandu.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Letter from Europe: At the Hay Festival, Democratizing Inspiration
item.description: The Hay Festival, which started in 1988, has since grown into one of the most prominent literary festivals in the world.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Canada’s Forced Schooling of Aboriginal Children Was ‘Cultural Genocide,’ Report Finds
item.description: The country’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission published a summary version of a report on the former policy of forcibly removing children from their families for schooling.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Aboriginal Canadians at a residential school in Fort Resolution, Northwest Territories, in a picture from around 1936.

item.title: Elmadere Journal: Anger and Grief Simmer in Turkey a Year After Soma Mine Disaster
item.description: Widows of coal miners say they have been left to face the future on their own after an explosion and fire at a mine in Soma killed 301 men in May 2014.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arife Kayrak, 47, lost her husband, Gungor, in the explosion and fire that tore through a coal mine in Soma, Turkey, in May 2014.

item.title: Gazans’ Hopes for Rebuilding After War Give Way to Deeper Despair
item.description: Hamas quietly initiated new import fees in an effort to cover the salaries of some 40,000 employees, raising prices in already depressed markets.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunset through a destroyed building on the Gaza shore. Many ruined structures remain from the war with Israel last summer.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can Kurds Shake Up Turkey's Politics?
item.description: A new party that attracts leftist and Kurdish nationalist voters could spell trouble for Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: U.S. Accuses Syria of Backing Islamic State's Aleppo Advance
item.description: The United States has accused the Syrian military of carrying out air strikes to help Islamic State fighters advance around the northern city of Aleppo, messages posted on the U.S. Embassy Syria official Twitter feed said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Push for Colombians to Stop Farming Coca Falls Short
item.description: The effort has gained new urgency since the government’s decision last month to halt an American-backed campaign to kill coca crops with spraying.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Stephen Ferry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anderson Navarro pruning cacao trees on his family farm. Many Colombian farmers have traded in their coca for other crops, growing cacao (for making chocolate), corn and plantains, while also raising cattle for milk and meat.
